entry.title: Combined summary - CTV BIP review
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev mailing list recently had discussions on several topics related to BIPs and their implementation. One of the topics focused on the burden placed on a BIP for its full implementation, which is considered more than necessary. Another topic discussed the use of an Eltoo-like protocol, which may be a problem unless it's an eltoo-like protocol. The third topic talked about the possibility of implementing OP_CAT or OP_SHA256STREAM in Bitcoin and how that would affect the use of CTV to create covenant chains with a finite number of steps.The fourth topic was about language cleanups and the legal definition of covenant. It was suggested that child covenants or inherited covenants should be specified, as opposed to legal or dictionary definitions, since this is a unique context within Bitcoin. Additionally, aj proposed a more useful definition of covenant within the context of Bitcoin as when the scriptPubKey of an unspent transaction output (utxo) restricts the scriptPubKey in the outputs of a transaction that spends that utxo.The fifth topic was about the discussion of activation methods for future soft forks and how it should be kept separate from the review of CTV BIP. It was suggested that BIPs should not advocate for any particular activation method but only mention what types of activation methods are possible. This separation of concerns would help reduce noise in conversations. Michael Folkson requested Eric and Luke not to discuss activation methods for soft forks on a thread for CTV BIP review because standalone OP_CTV is not the only current soft fork proposal, and there will likely be more.Luke Dashjr provided a detailed review of the CTV BIP, expressing concern about its readiness and stating that BIP 9 should not be used due to known flaws and vulnerabilities. He also questioned some of the claims made in the BIP and suggested alternative approaches for certain use cases. In response, Jeremy Rubin thanked Luke for his review and stated that he will make a PR to clear up some language cleanups. Although he agrees with the need for drafting BIPs for specific use cases, he is skeptical about its overall approach.In an email exchange between Luke Dashjr and Eric Voskuil, they discussed the compatibility of soft forks with regards to the Bitcoin consensus protocol. Dashjr argued that soft forks are not backward compatible without "hash power enforcement" which can only be done by miners, and that observed chain splits have occurred in large scale soft fork deployments which were resolved through hash power enforcement. Voskuil disagreed, stating that enforcement of the Bitcoin consensus protocol is by users, not miners, and that soft forks never produce a chain split. Dashjr also called out Voskuil for making misleading statements about BIP8 and Taproot activation, accusing him of deception.Finally, there was a discussion about the use of BIP8 for Taproot activation. It was pointed out that BIP8 achieved consensus for Taproot activation despite not gaining sufficient support. However, it was also noted that ST was some technical tweaks to BIP9 and not a full implementation of BIP8. Michael suggests that discussing activation methods for soft forks on a thread for CTV BIP review might give the mistaken impression that OP_CTV is the next soft fork to be activated, which is mere speculation at this point.
